articles.headline: Gas Prices Modestly Lower as Driving Season Starts
articles.snippet: The cost of a gallon of gasoline is dropping, especially on the East Coast, because of growing oil supplies and a decline in global crude oil prices.
articles.abstract: The cost of a gallon of gasoline is dropping, especially on the East Coast, because of growing oil supplies and a decline in global crude oil prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As the Memorial Day weekend and the summer driving season approach, gasoline prices are easing. But most drivers will find prices only modestly lower than a year ago.

articles.headline: After Barreling Ahead in Recession, China Finally Slows
articles.snippet: China, which has driven global growth as the United States and Europe struggled, is seeing a real estate downturn, stalling exports and a drop in consumer confidence.
articles.abstract: China, which has driven global growth as the United States and Europe struggled, is seeing a real estate downturn, stalling exports and a drop in consumer confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: XI’AN, China — A nationwide real estate downturn, stalling exports and declining consumer confidence have produced what a Chinese cabinet adviser, quoted on the official government Web site on Thursday, characterized as a “sharp slowdown in the economy.”

articles.headline: Colleges for Profit Are Growing, With Federal Help
articles.snippet: While state and local governments spend less on higher education, the volume of federally guaranteed loans to students at commercial colleges continues to grow.
articles.abstract: While state and local governments spend less on higher education, the volume of federally guaranteed loans to students at commercial colleges continues to grow.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are a lot of government subsidies, and in the current fiscal atmosphere many are shrinking by necessity. What appears to be lacking is any rational way of deciding which should shrink.

articles.headline: Iran Is Seeking Lebanon Stake as Syria Totters
articles.snippet: Iran’s eagerness to shower money on Lebanon is the latest indication of just how worried Tehran is at the prospect that Syria’s leader could fall.
articles.abstract: Iran’s eagerness to shower money on Lebanon is the latest indication of just how worried Tehran is at the prospect that Syria’s leader could fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: TANNOURINE, Lebanon — The Islamic republic of Iran recently offered to build a dam in this scenic alpine village, high in the Christian heartland of Lebanon.

articles.headline: New Orleans Newspaper Scales Back in Sign of Print Upheaval
articles.snippet: Circulation and staff reductions at The Times-Picayune of New Orleans and three Alabama newspapers are the latest instances of reorganization in a rapidly changing industry.
articles.abstract: Circulation and staff reductions at The Times-Picayune of New Orleans and three Alabama newspapers are the latest instances of reorganization in a rapidly changing industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Times-Picayune, a 175-year-old fixture in New Orleans and a symbol of the city’s gritty resilience during Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath, has buckled under the pressures of the modern newspaper market.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Christine Haughney

articles.headline: In Spain, Bank Transfers Reflect Broader Fears
articles.snippet: The possibility of mini-runs on banks spreading from Greece to bigger countries could pose a much greater risk than a Greek exit from the euro zone.
articles.abstract: The possibility of mini-runs on banks spreading from Greece to bigger countries could pose a much greater risk than a Greek exit from the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ángel de la Peña, a Spanish government worker, is seriously considering the once unthinkable: converting some of his savings from euros to British pounds.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Chinese Power Player Places Risky Bet on Moviegoing
articles.snippet: Wang Jianlin, a rags-to-riches mogul, is taking over AMC Entertainment and promising to integrate it into a global brand called the Wanda Group.
articles.abstract: Wang Jianlin, a rags-to-riches mogul, is taking over AMC Entertainment and promising to integrate it into a global brand called the Wanda Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Hollywood studios, facing steep challenges in the North American movie market, are taking more interest in China.

articles.headline: A Mining Rush in the Upper Peninsula
articles.snippet: With copper trading at high prices, a remote area of Michigan is rediscovering its mining roots, raising hopes that the region will recover from a long slump.
articles.abstract: With copper trading at high prices, a remote area of Michigan is rediscovering its mining roots, raising hopes that the region will recover from a long slump.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRONWOOD, Mich. — On the far northern reaches of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, James Jacques drove on a rutted logging road to an old mining shaft surrounded by a chain-link fence.

articles.headline: Small Investors Seek Answers to the Confusion of Facebook Trading
articles.snippet: Nasdaq said 30 million Facebook shares were executed improperly Friday because of technical flaws, and retail investors have spent the week looking for someone to address their losses.
articles.abstract: Nasdaq said 30 million Facebook shares were executed improperly Friday because of technical flaws, and retail investors have spent the week looking for someone to address their losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Hoag thought he had dodged the botched initial public offering of Facebook stock when he canceled his order last week for 100 of the company’s shares. This week, Mr. Hoag, 63, a property manager in Tennessee, learned from his Scottrade broker that he was being charged $3,805 for the shares anyway, plus a commission fee.

articles.headline: Egypt Race Pits Aide to Mubarak Against Islamist
articles.snippet: The race to become the Egyptian president is shaping up as a contest between two of Egypt’s most powerful, polarizing forces: political Islam and the military.
articles.abstract: The race to become the Egyptian president is shaping up as a contest between two of Egypt’s most powerful, polarizing forces: political Islam and the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The runoff to become Egypt’s first freely elected president is shaping up as a contest between two of the most powerful and polarizing forces in Egyptian society: political Islam or the leadership of the past.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Companies Get Blunt Counsel on Greek Upheaval
articles.snippet: Lawyers’ advice to corporate clients is frank: Remove cash and other liquid assets from Greece and prepare to take a short-term hit on any other investments.
articles.abstract: Lawyers’ advice to corporate clients is frank: Remove cash and other liquid assets from Greece and prepare to take a short-term hit on any other investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — What can companies do when the legally impossible becomes reasonably probable?
